review.title: Analysis of the Effect of Dependency Information on Predicate-Argument Structure Analysis and Zero Anaphora Resolution
review.abstract: This paper investigates and analyzes the effect of dependency information on predicate-argument structure analysis (PASA) and zero anaphora resolution (ZAR) for Japanese, and shows that a straightforward approach of PASA and ZAR works effectively even if dependency information was not available. We constructed an analyzer that directly predicts relationships of predicates and arguments with their semantic roles from a POS-tagged corpus. The features of the system are designed to compensate for the absence of syntactic information by using features used in dependency parsing as a reference. We also constructed analyzers that use the oracle dependency and the real dependency parsing results, and compared with the system that does not use any syntactic information to verify that the improvement provided by dependencies is not crucial.

sections.heading: 3 Pointwise Predicate-Argument Structure Analysis
sections.text: Pointwise PASA (PWPASA) is a framework that predicts the relationships between each word in a document and a given predicate independently of other predictors using a binary classifier (Yoshino et al., 2013). One of the advantages of the pointwise approach is that the classifier does not depend on other tasks of the NLP whose predictive accuracy may not be high enough (Neubig et al., 2011; Mori and Neubig, 2011). Essentially, the PWPASA does not require global structures such as dependencies and can be used to build a PASA model that does not refer to dependency information.

sections.heading: 4 Experimental Evaluation
sections.text: We investigated the effects of dependency information on PASA, including ZAR, by comparing the proposed analyzer, which does not use dependency information, and a more traditional system, which uses dependency information. All experimental conditions except dependency information are the same. We constructed two systems that do not use dependency information; PWFeat and PWFeat + Lang, and three systems that use dependency information; oracle dependence (PWFeat + Lang + Dep (oracle)); real analysis results (PWFeat + Lang + Dep (analyzed)); and simulated analysis results with 20% errors (PWFeat + Lang + Dep (20% error). The function type used is specified in name; PWFeat means the use of functions for PWPASA; Lang means the use of language-dependent features; and Dep means the use of dependency information characteristics. For 2002, we used a paraphrase based on the PWP8% of the result, which includes a Cabogoto.

sections.heading: 4.1 Experimental Setting
sections.text: We used the NAIST Text Corpus (NTC) (Iida et al., 2007b), a corpus that is publicly available1. The documents are annotated with predicate-argument relationships and co-preferences.The sentences also have annotations at a lower level: word boundaries, POS tags, chunks and phrase dependencies. sections.heading: 4.3 Effect of language specific features
sections.text: We have also prepared the analyzer that does not use language-specific features of the PWPASA (features described in Section 3.3) to verify the universality of the constructed PWFeat + Lang. Compared to PWFeat and PWFeat + Lang in Table 2, the overall accuracy (ALL-ALL) was reduced by 1.08 points due to the absence of language-specific features. It shows that there is a degree of universality of the PWFeat + Lang model that covers dependency information with indirect features.

sections.heading: 5 Related Studies
sections.text: In the CoNLL Common Task 2004 (Carreras and Ma rquez, 2004; Hacioglu et al., 2004), some systems addressed SRL only with flat syntax structures; chunks and clauses. In CoNLL Common Task 2005 (Carreras and Ma rquez, 2005; Koomen et al., 2005), deeper syntax structures, dependencies, are provided, and the best system exceeded the best system of the CoNLL Common Task 2004. However, the effects of errors are not analyzed in depth, and these tasks aim only at identifying semantic roles between elements in the same sentences. While applications that use PAS require higher accuracy of PASA in different areas (Imamura et al., 2014), it is difficult, however, to improve the accuracy of PASA on a variety of domains.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: This paper illustrated the effect of dependency information in a PASA by comparing the analyzer that does not use dependency information, an analyzer that uses oracle dependency information, and an analyzer that uses real parsing results including parsing errors. It showed that dependency information improves PASA. Since analyzers that use dependency information require dependency annotations and parser constructions, the cost is very high, which is disproportionate to improving accuracy, as shown in Figure 6. Experimental results showed that the indirect features that compensate for the absence of dependency features worked well enough. Taking into account the cost of generating dependency information, accuracy makes sense in realistic situations. We plan to design a framework for rapid data preparation and apply the system to a variety of areas in the future.
